de.susebox.java.util
Class InputStreamTokenizer

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--de.susebox.java.util.AbstractTokenizer
        |
        +--de.susebox.java.util.InputStreamTokenizer
All Implemented Interfaces:
Tokenizer
public class InputStreamTokenizer
extends AbstractTokenizer

The class extends the AbstractTokenizer and provides the Tokenizer functionality for Reader sources, e.g. InputStreamReader or StringReader.

The name is somewhat misleading since the class does actually work with every Reader implementation, but InputStreamReader are probably the most important ones.

Author:
Heiko Blau
See Also:
Tokenizer, AbstractTokenizer, Reader, InputStreamReader

_reader

protected java.io.Reader _reader
Constructor Detail

InputStreamTokenizer

public InputStreamTokenizer()
Default constructor. Standard input System.in is used to construct the input stream reader.

InputStreamTokenizer

public InputStreamTokenizer(java.io.Reader reader)
Constructor that takes a instantiated InputStream. If null is given then standard input is used (System.in.

See Also:
InputStream

InputStreamTokenizer

public InputStreamTokenizer(java.io.Reader reader,
                            int flags)
Constructor that takes a instantiated InputStream and the tokenizer control flags. If null is given for the stream then standard input is used (System.in. For the tokenizer control flags use a combination of the F_... constants from the Tokenizer for this parameter.

Parameters:
reader - input stream to be used for reading
flags - tokenizer control flags
See Also:
InputStream, Tokenizer

InputStreamTokenizer

public InputStreamTokenizer(java.io.Reader reader,
                            int flags,
                            java.lang.String whitespaces,
                            java.lang.String separators)
Constructor that takes a instantiated InputStream, the tokenizer control flags, whitespace and separator strings. If null is given for the stream then standard input is used (System.in. For the tokenizer control flags use a combination of the F_... constants from the Tokenizer for this parameter.

Parameters:
reader - input stream to be used for reading
flags - tokenizer control flags
whitespaces - the whitespace set
separators - the set of separating characters
See Also:
InputStream, Tokenizer
Method Detail

read

protected int read(char[] cbuf,
                   int offset,
                   int maxChars)
            throws java.lang.Exception
Implements the abstract method AbstractTokenizer.read(char[], int, int) by wrapping the InputStreamReader.read() call of the JDK standard class InputStreamReader.

Specified by:
read in class AbstractTokenizer
Parameters:
cbuf - buffer to receive data
offset - position from where the data should be inserted in cbuf
maxChars - maximum number of characters to be read into cbuf
Returns:
actually read characters or -1 on an end-of-file condition
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - anything that could happen during read, most likely IOException

setSource

public void setSource(java.io.Reader reader)
Setting the source for the tokenizer. Note that any data read from a previous source are lost. Position, line and column counting will start from 0. With this method it is possible to use one tokenizer on more than one source. A common example is a list of files that are to be processed.

Parameters:
reader - the new source for the read(char[], int, int) method

getSource

public java.io.Reader getSource()
Retrieving the current source. Note that the Tokenizer probably read ahead a huge part or even all data from this source.

Returns:
the current source of the tokenizer
